description: Originated 1400–50 from late Middle English turrible, from thoryble, from Latin thūribulum (“censer”), equivalent to thūs (“incense”) (root: thūr-) (from Ancient Greek θύος (thúos, “burnt offering”)) + -bulum (“instrumental suffix”).

entries.meaning: A censer, especially one hanging on a chain.
examples: The celebrant may fill the thurible with incense before the entrance, or may instruct the thurifer to do so.
